channel.title: Ars-Technica on Panz3r News
channel.description: Recent content in Ars-Technica on news.panz3r.dev

item.title: The weekend’s best tech deals: Nintendo Switch Lite, MacBook Air, and more
item.description: Dealmaster also has deals on Dell monitors, good board games, and portable SSDs.

item.title: When science breaks bad: A rogue gallery of history’s worst scientists
item.description: A new book catalogs some of the greatest ethical lapses done in the name of science.

item.title: Quest for “green” cement draws big name investors to $300B industry
item.description: Start-ups and venture capitalists are joining concrete makers against a hard problem.

item.title: Feds indict “The Bull” for allegedly selling insider stock info on the dark web
item.description: Data allegedly sold individually or through weekly or monthly subscriptions.

item.title: Cheat-maker brags of computer-vision auto-aim that works on “any game”
item.description: Capture cards, input hardware, and machine learning get around system-level lockdowns.

item.title: Rupert Murdoch’s answer to Google News is dead after only 18 months
item.description: The shuttered news aggregator offered stories mainly from right-leaning sources.

item.title: NYC ePrix: It’s time for Formula E’s annual visit to America
item.description: We check in with one of our favorite series ahead of this weekend’s races.

item.title: The FBI’s honeypot Pixel 4a gets detailed in new report
item.description: FBI honeypot phones are now public—and showing up on the secondary market.

item.title: How to watch Branson’s flight, which Jeff Bezos is still hopping mad about
item.description: “New Shepard was designed to fly above the Kármán line.”

item.title: World record for most expensive video game auction is now $870,000
item.description: Leapfrogs past April 2021’s previous world record auction for boxed SMB1 by 24 percent.

item.title: With little remaining of Champlain Towers, how will we find answers?
item.description: Researchers discuss the methods NIST can use to find the cause of a tragedy.

item.title: Biden urges FCC to undo Pai’s legacy—but it can’t until he picks a third Democrat
item.description: Biden wants FCC to lower prices and protect consumers, but he must break 2-2 deadlock.

item.title: Amid criticism, FDA narrows use of $56K Alzheimer’s drug, calls for probe [Updated]
item.description: FDA now says drug should only go to those with mild disease—the only patients tested.

item.title: “Bad mergers” and noncompete clauses targeted in Biden executive order
item.description: Sweeping order tries to counter rising corporate consolidation.

item.title: Google’s Nest Hub is the best bedside smart display—and sleep tracking helps
item.description: Adding sleep tracking bolsters its bedside utility, but the feature could use more depth.

item.title: Rocket Report: SLS not available for science, OneWeb reaches milestone
item.description: “There is great concern about this engine development.”

item.title: Black Widow review: ScarJo’s sendoff is MCU’s best standalone film yet
item.description: Florence Pugh’s scene-stealing turn caps a tremendous MCU mix of action, acting.

item.title: The Windows 11 insider build is surprisingly unpolished and unfinished
item.description: Windows 11 looks to be a decent upgrade, but not one to lose sleep over missing.

item.title: Morgan Stanley discloses data breach that resulted from Accellion FTA hacks
item.description: Financial services firm says data was stolen by exploiting flaws discovered in December.

item.title: All fans banned from Tokyo Olympics as COVID cases rise, delta spreads
item.description: The prime minister also asked bars and restaurants not to serve alcohol.

item.title: It’s a mad, mad multiverse as Marvel drops first trailer for What If…?
item.description: “Every universe is different. Each one unique.”

item.title: GOP’s Big Tech plan ignores consumers, targets “censorship” of Republicans instead
item.description: Republican antitrust plan is all about supposed bias, never mentions competition.

item.title: New fabric passively cools whatever it’s covering—including you
item.description: Structured fabric reflects most light, still radiates in the IR.

item.title: What fractals, Fibonacci, and the golden ratio have to do with cauliflower
item.description: Self-selected mutations during domestication drastically changed shape over time

item.title: New Google Pay debit card lets you actually spend the money people send you
item.description: A virtual debit card lets you skip transferring money to a bank account.

item.title: Google “bought off Samsung” to limit app store competition, 36 states allege
item.description: “Google has taken steps to close the ecosystem from competition.”

item.title: Four new electric platforms, five gigafactories: Stellantis’ EV plan
item.description: The world’s fourth-largest OEM just laid out its electrification strategy.

item.title: Reconstructing Roman industrial engineering
item.description: How a special design increased the efficiency of an ancient watermill.

item.title: mRNA vaccine technology moves to flu: Moderna says trial has begun
item.description: Moderna aims for one seasonal shot for flu, COVID-19, respiratory viruses RSV and HMPV.

item.title: OnePlus admits to throttling 300 popular apps with recent update
item.description: Chrome performance tanks 85-75 percent in some tests.

item.title: Microsoft’s emergency patch fails to fix critical “PrintNightmare” vulnerability
item.description: Game-over code-execution attacks are still possible even after fix is installed.

item.title: Pacific Northwest heatwave “virtually impossible” without climate change
item.description: Rapid analysis shows it would be hard to do this in a cooler world.

item.title: Netflix gives us our first look at Zack Snyder’s heist film Army of Thieves
item.description: It’s a prequel to Snyder’s Army of the Dead, so yes, there will also be zombies.

item.title: Trump sues Twitter and Facebook for banning him, claims “trillions” in damages
item.description: Trump’s “free speech” case is likely doomed by First Amendment and Section 230.

item.title: Dozens of Chinese phone games now require facial scans to play at night
item.description: After a 2018 test, “Midnight Patrol” system officially rolls out to 60 Tencent games.

item.title: The Chime banking app has been closing accounts, not returning money
item.description: Chime isn’t actually a bank—it’s a “neobank” with less federal regulation.

item.title: Why the password isn’t dead quite yet
item.description: Everyone hates the old ways of authentication. But change comes with its own drawbacks.

item.title: Increasingly, the ULA-Blue Origin marriage is an unhappy one
item.description: “It does no good to throw Blue Origin under the bus.”

item.title: Biden’s right-to-repair order could stop companies from blocking DIY fixes
item.description: Executive order comes amid growing state, federal push to open repair process.

item.title: Cluster full of black holes may be spitting out stars
item.description: If the researchers are right, globular clusters may end up full of black holes.

item.title: No driver? No problem—this is the Indy Autonomous Challenge
item.description: Ars meets the college engineers who hope to revolutionize racing.

item.title: Google Chat review: Terrible as a Slack clone, good as a consumer chat app
item.description: Google’s enterprise-first chat app is only occasionally awkward for consumers.

item.title: What the “OLED Model” means for the future of Nintendo Switch
item.description: Who’s it for? Where’s the 4K support? And does Nintendo really need it?

item.title: Delta variant slams Missouri as ICUs fill and ventilators run low
item.description: Cases and hospitalizations surge amid the low vaccination rates and the spread of delta.

item.title: Up to 1,500 businesses infected in one of the worst ransomware attacks ever
item.description: Mass compromise is having cascading effects around the world.

item.title: GameStop’s Summer Sale is live with a number of good Switch and PS5 deals
item.description: Dealmaster also has deals on MacBooks, the OnePlus 9, Roku streamers, and more.

item.title: Pentagon kills Microsoft’s $10B JEDI cloud contract, says tech is now outdated
item.description: Amazon’s legal stall tactics seem to have paid off.

item.title: NASA’s helicopter on Mars just keeps flying and flying
item.description: For NASA, taking some risk has paid off handsomely.

item.title: “Broadcom is a monopolist”: FTC orders chipmaker to stop illegal tactics
item.description: Firm “illegally” dominated set-top box and modem chips, must stop exclusivity deals.

item.title: No, open source Audacity audio editor is not “spyware”
item.description: The community’s telemetry concerns were received and addressed two months ago.

item.title: Bitcoin power plant is turning a 12,000-year-old glacial lake into a hot tub
item.description: Private equity’s cryptocurrency experiment pushes more costs on the public.

item.title: Microsoft’s Surface Duo falls even lower, now almost $1000 off
item.description: 71 percent off is a sad ending for Microsoft’s first self-branded Android phone.

item.title: Bentley has a new plug-in hybrid Flying Spur sedan on the way
item.description: First battery Bentley due in 2025; no more combustion engines after 2030.

item.title: Spiders eating snakes, oh my! Here are the photographs to prove it
item.description: Some species of spider can conquer snakes that are 10 to 30 times their size.

item.title: Peugeot plans to win Le Mans in 2022 with this 9X8 hybrid prototype
item.description: The French Lion last tasted victory at La Sarthe in 2009.

item.title: Meet the Switch Pro: $350 “OLED Model” launches on October 8
item.description: Bigger, brighter screen and a new kickstand, but no processing power improvements?

item.title: Evolution of the dad
item.description: Most male mammals have little to do with their kids. Why is our own species different?

item.title: Did lead poisoning cause downfall of Roman Empire? The jury is still out
item.description: A new video from the American Chemical Society revisits longstanding academic debate
